text: today on x cast a bomb kills at least 25
people in a densely populated
neighborhood in Syria's capital the US
economy adds 200,000 new jobs in
December raising hopes for an economic
recovery a bomb tore through a crowded
neighborhood in Damascus today killing
at least 25 people and wounding 46 more
it seemed to underline a potentially new
chapter in the Syrian uprising which
began in mid-march the Syrian government
blamed terrorists for the bombing and it
said the fingerprints of okada were all
over the attack that charge was the
exact same one the government levy two
weeks ago when bombings also struck the
capital Damascus killing dozens more but
some dissident figures in groups opposed
to President Bashar less that have
suggested the government itself carried
out the attacks is a way to solely the
image of the Opposition in the broadest
terms the attack underlined what is
increasingly complicated insurgency an
observer mission from the Arab League
arrived two weeks ago and while
opposition groups have complained that
the Arab League has done little to stop
the bloodshed the very arrival of the
team seems to have inaugurated a new
chapter in the uprising photos that have
erupted every Friday for nearly 10
months now seem to have a new momentum
but the general sense up there not only
among the opposition but also among
supporters of the government is that the
months ahead may prove bloody they may
prove unpredictable and the uprising
itself may take turns that no one has
yet seen before we're starting to
rebound we're moving in the right
direction we have made real progress now
is not the time to stuff the Labor
Department announced on Friday that
employers added 200,000 jobs in December
this was a final glass-half-full moment
for the economy in that we have been
watching jobs were bump along at a
steady but uninspiring rate of between
100 and 150 thousand jobs and to finally
see employers bumping up to 200,000 gave
people more hope certainly in this
political campaign season when all the
candidates are pounding and pounding and
pounding on the economy
go to work to get America back to work
this slightly changes the landscape
bright spots have been manufacturing and
while that was tapering off a little bit
in the fall it seems to have come back
in December so that's good sign this is
something that has come up on the
campaign trail in Iowa Rick Santorum
talked a lot about manufacturing and
even proposed that he would levy 0%
corporate taxes on companies that bring
back factories from overseas and so when
Republican purists say to me well why
are you treating manufacturing differing
different than retail I say because
Walmart's not moving to China and taking
their jobs with them whether that would
create as many jobs as he thinks it
would is up for questioning given that a
lot of the jobs that have been lost in
manufacturing over the past decade have
to do with automation rather than jobs
going overseas despite the good news
into summer this is inevitably going to
be a big topic for the campaign trail
unemployment is still at eight point
five percent there's still more than 13
million people out of work so they're
still going to be a lot of talk of how
we can spur the economy to grow and for
employers to add more job
